title: Psalms Chapter 101 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 101 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 101 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 101.

questions.question: According to Psalms 101:1, what will David sing about?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:1 states that David will sing of mercy and judgment unto the LORD.

questions.question: In Psalms 101:2, how does David say he will behave himself?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:2 says David will behave himself wisely in a perfect way.

questions.question: According to Psalms 101:3, what will David set no wicked thing before?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:3 declares David will set no wicked thing before his eyes.

questions.question: What will depart from David according to Psalms 101:4?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:4 says a froward heart shall depart from David.

questions.question: Who does David say he will cut off in Psalms 101:5?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:5 states David will cut off him who privily slandereth his neighbour.

questions.question: According to Psalms 101:6, whose eyes will David keep upon?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:6 says David's eyes shall be upon the faithful of the land.

questions.question: Who will not dwell in David's house as per Psalms 101:7?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:7 declares that he who worketh deceit shall not dwell within David's house.

questions.question: According to Psalms 101:8, what will David do to the wicked of the land?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:8 states David will early destroy all the wicked of the land.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 101:3 says David will set many wicked things before his eyes.
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:3 clearly says David will set no wicked thing before his eyes.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 101:4 states David will know a wicked person.
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:4 says David will not know a wicked person.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 101:7, liars will be allowed to stay in David's sight.
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:7 states that liars shall not tarry in David's sight.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 101:2: 'I will walk within my house with a ______ heart.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:2 says, 'I will walk within my house with a perfect heart.'

questions.question: What kind of heart does Psalms 101:5 say David will not suffer?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:5 states that a proud heart will not be suffered by David.

questions.question: According to Psalms 101:6, who shall serve David?
options: He that walketh in a perfect way
questions.correctAnswer: He that walketh in a perfect way
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:6 says he that walketh in a perfect way shall serve David.

questions.question: According to Psalms 101:1, to whom will David sing?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:1 states David will sing unto thee, O LORD.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 101 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 101 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with maintaining integrity at work. Based on Psalms 101, what biblical truth would you share about dealing with deceit?
options: Deceitful workers should not be tolerated in your presence
Deceit is acceptable if it benefits your family
Ignoring deceit is wise to maintain peace
Deceitful behavior is a sign of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Deceitful workers should not be tolerated in your presence
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:7 states that those who work deceit shall not dwell within the house, emphasizing the need for honesty and integrity. This aligns with verses 3 and 5 about rejecting wicked works and proud hearts.

questions.question: How does Psalms 101 teach us about guarding our hearts and eyes against temptation?
options: By setting no wicked thing before our eyes
By trusting others to protect us
questions.correctAnswer: By setting no wicked thing before our eyes
questions.explanation: Verse 3 clearly states the psalmist will set no wicked thing before his eyes and hates the work of those who turn aside, teaching us to guard our eyes and hearts actively.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 101, what attitude should a Christian have toward those who slander their neighbors?
options: They should be joined in fellowship
questions.explanation: Verse 5 teaches that those who privately slander neighbors will be cut off, highlighting the seriousness of slander and the need to avoid association with such behavior.

questions.question: What does Psalms 101 say about walking 'within my house with a perfect heart' and its relation to personal devotion?
options: It shows commitment to living wisely and purely at home
It means ignoring problems outside the home
It encourages only external religious acts
questions.correctAnswer: It shows commitment to living wisely and purely at home
questions.explanation: Verse 2 expresses the psalmist's desire to behave wisely and walk within his house with a perfect heart, emphasizing personal holiness and devotion starting within the family environment.

questions.question: A believer wants to cultivate humility and avoid pride. What counsel from Psalms 101 would you give regarding a proud heart?
options: Do not suffer a proud heart
Proud hearts are signs of strength
questions.correctAnswer: Do not suffer a proud heart
questions.explanation: Verse 5 clearly states the psalmist will not suffer him that hath a high look and a proud heart, teaching the importance of humility and rejecting pride.

questions.question: How does Psalms 101 guide Christians in choosing their close companions?
options: Keep company with the faithful and those who walk in a perfect way
questions.correctAnswer: Keep company with the faithful and those who walk in a perfect way
questions.explanation: Verse 6 emphasizes the psalmist's eyes being upon the faithful so they may dwell with him, teaching believers to surround themselves with godly and faithful companions.

questions.question: What does Psalms 101 teach about dealing with wicked people in the community?
options: Early destruction and cutting off of wicked doers
questions.correctAnswer: Early destruction and cutting off of wicked doers
questions.explanation: Verse 8 declares the intention to destroy the wicked early and cut off all wicked doers from the city of the LORD, teaching decisive action against persistent wickedness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 101 encourage believers to live with integrity in their daily walk?
options: By behaving wisely in a perfect way
questions.correctAnswer: By behaving wisely in a perfect way
questions.explanation: Verse 2 shows the psalmist's commitment to behaving wisely and walking with a perfect heart, encouraging believers to live with integrity and wisdom daily.

questions.question: What is the relationship between mercy and judgment as taught in Psalms 101?
options: Both are subjects to be sung unto the LORD
Mercy is more important than judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Both are subjects to be sung unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 1 states 'I will sing of mercy and judgment unto thee, O LORD,' showing both are integral parts of God's character and worthy of praise.

questions.question: A Christian asks how to resist associating with wickedness. What does Psalms 101 say about knowing wicked people?
options: A froward heart shall depart and wicked persons shall not be known
It is good to befriend all people
Knowing wicked people is unavoidable and acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: A froward heart shall depart and wicked persons shall not be known
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states the psalmist will not know a wicked person and that a froward heart shall depart, teaching separation from wickedness in association and attitude.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 101, a person should tolerate a proud heart in fellowship for the sake of unity.
questions.explanation: Verse 5 explicitly says the psalmist will not suffer a proud heart, indicating that pride should not be tolerated even for unity's sake.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 101 encourages early and decisive action against wickedness in the community.
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states the psalmist will early destroy all the wicked of the land to cut off wicked doers, highlighting the need for decisive action against evil.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 101 teaches, "I will walk within my house with a ____ heart."
questions.explanation: Verse 2 clearly states the psalmist will walk within his house with a perfect heart, underscoring the importance of purity and integrity in personal life.

questions.question: How does Psalms 101 instruct believers to respond to those who tell lies?
options: They shall not tarry in the psalmist's sight
They should be forgiven without correction
They should be encouraged to continue
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not tarry in the psalmist's sight
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states that those who tell lies shall not tarry in the psalmist's sight, teaching the importance of rejecting falsehood and promoting truth.

questions.question: What practical Christian application can be drawn from Psalms 101 about spiritual discipline and prayer?
options: A longing for God's presence and singing of His mercy and judgment
Avoiding prayer because it is difficult
questions.correctAnswer: A longing for God's presence and singing of His mercy and judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 1 expresses the psalmist's desire to sing of mercy and judgment unto the LORD, showing a heart devoted to worship and spiritual discipline.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 101 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 101.

questions.question: In Psalms 101, David promises to sing of two themes. What are they?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:1 states, 'I will sing of mercy and judgment,' indicating these two themes are central to the Psalm.

questions.question: What does David commit to walking within his house with, according to Psalms 101?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:2 says, 'I will walk within my house with a perfect heart,' highlighting David’s commitment to integrity in his personal life.

questions.question: According to Psalms 101, what kind of things will David set before his eyes?
options: Only the law of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:3 declares, 'I will set no wicked thing before mine eyes,' showing David’s resolve to avoid exposure to evil.

questions.question: In Psalms 101, how does David describe his attitude toward a froward heart and wicked persons?
options: He will depart from a froward heart and not know a wicked person
He will forgive all and seek to convert them
He will judge but keep them close
He will tolerate but not approve
questions.correctAnswer: He will depart from a froward heart and not know a wicked person
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:4 states, 'A froward heart shall depart from me: I will not know a wicked person,' indicating separation from evil.

questions.question: Who does David say he will cut off in Psalms 101?
options: Those who slander their neighbor privily
Those who do not pay taxes
Those who are weak in faith
questions.correctAnswer: Those who slander their neighbor privily
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:5 says, 'Whoso privily slandereth his neighbour, him will I cut off,' showing intolerance for secret slander.

questions.question: What kind of people will David keep his eyes upon, according to Psalms 101?
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:6 states, 'Mine eyes shall be upon the faithful of the land,' emphasizing David’s focus on loyalty and righteousness.

questions.question: According to Psalms 101, what will happen to those who work deceit or tell lies?
options: They shall not dwell in David’s house nor tarry in his sight
They will be forgiven if they repent
They will be given a warning
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not dwell in David’s house nor tarry in his sight
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:7 says, 'He that worketh deceit shall not dwell within my house: he that telleth lies shall not tarry in my sight,' showing exclusion from David’s fellowship.

questions.question: What does David promise to do early in Psalms 101?
options: Destroy all the wicked of the land
Build a temple for the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Destroy all the wicked of the land
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:8 declares, 'I will early destroy all the wicked of the land,' indicating David’s commitment to purge evil promptly.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 101 emphasizes walking in a perfect way as part of wise behavior.
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:2 states, 'I will behave myself wisely in a perfect way,' showing the connection between wisdom and perfection in conduct.

questions.question: Which of the following best represents the literary structure observed in Psalms 101 concerning the separation from wickedness?
options: Chiasm emphasizing avoidance and cutting off evil
Simple parallelism repeating the same theme
A lament followed by praise structure
An acrostic pattern based on Hebrew alphabet
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm emphasizing avoidance and cutting off evil
questions.explanation: The Psalm displays a chiastic pattern with David’s avoidance of evil (vv.3-4) balanced by the cutting off of the wicked (vv.5-8), highlighting separation from sin.

questions.question: The Hebrew word translated as 'perfect' in Psalms 101:2 and 6 (כָּמֵה or תָּמִים) connotes what kind of moral quality?
questions.explanation: The Hebrew term תָּמִים (tamim) connotes wholeness and integrity rather than absolute sinlessness, highlighting uprightness in relational and ethical behavior.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most closely echoes the theme of walking blamelessly as expressed in Psalms 101:2?
questions.explanation: Ephesians 5:8-10 exhorts believers to walk as children of light, doing what is pleasing to God, paralleling David’s commitment to walk in a perfect way.

questions.question: How does the commitment in Psalms 101:1 to sing of mercy and judgment reflect a broader biblical tension found in Proverbs?
options: It balances God’s justice with His compassion
It rejects human wisdom in favor of divine mystery
It focuses solely on mercy at the expense of law
It denies the need for judgment in the new covenant
questions.correctAnswer: It balances God’s justice with His compassion
questions.explanation: The Psalm’s focus on mercy and judgment mirrors Proverbs’ themes where God’s justice is tempered by mercy, showing a holistic view of God’s character.

questions.question: What cultural or historical practice does David’s promise to 'cut off' slanderers (Psalms 101:5) reflect from the Ancient Near East context?
options: Righteous leaders maintaining social order by removing harmful individuals
A ritual cleansing involving public shaming
Sacrificial offerings to appease offended parties
questions.correctAnswer: Righteous leaders maintaining social order by removing harmful individuals
questions.explanation: In the Ancient Near East, kings were responsible for preserving justice and social order by eliminating slander and treachery, which threatened communal stability.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 101 suggests that the king’s household should include those who work deceit and tell lies.
questions.explanation: Psalms 101:7 explicitly states that those who work deceit or tell lies shall not dwell in the king’s house or remain in his sight.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 101 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 101 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 101:1, what two themes does David declare he will sing about to the LORD?
questions.explanation: Psalm 101:1 explicitly states that David will sing of mercy and judgment. These themes reflect God's character as merciful yet just, consistent with Exodus 34:6-7, Micah 6:8, Romans 2:5-6, Hebrews 4:16, and Revelation 15:3.

questions.question: In Psalms 101:2, David speaks of walking within his house with what kind of heart?
questions.explanation: David declares in Psalm 101:2 his intent to walk with a perfect heart, signifying integrity and wholehearted devotion. This aligns with Proverbs 4:23, 1 Kings 8:61, Matthew 5:8, and Ephesians 5:9, which emphasize purity of heart before God.

questions.question: What does David vow in Psalms 101:3 regarding wicked things before his eyes?
options: He will set no wicked thing before his eyes
He will seek to understand wickedness
questions.correctAnswer: He will set no wicked thing before his eyes
questions.explanation: Psalm 101:3 states David’s commitment to reject wickedness visually and morally, reflecting God's call for holiness (1 Peter 1:16), avoidance of sin (Proverbs 4:25-27), and the command to fix our eyes on Jesus (Hebrews 12:2).

questions.question: According to Psalms 101:4, what kind of heart will depart from David?
questions.explanation: Psalm 101:4 says a froward (perverse or crooked) heart shall depart from David, indicating his rejection of rebellion against God. This is consistent with Proverbs 3:5-6, Jeremiah 17:9, Ezekiel 36:26, and James 4:8 calling for a pure and obedient heart.

questions.question: Who will David cut off according to Psalms 101:5?
options: One who slanders his neighbor in secret
questions.correctAnswer: One who slanders his neighbor in secret
questions.explanation: Psalm 101:5 commits to cutting off those who secretly slander neighbors, condemning hypocrisy and pride. This is echoed in Proverbs 10:18, Leviticus 19:16, Romans 1:29-30, and James 4:11, highlighting the seriousness of slander and pride.

questions.question: In Psalms 101:6, David says his eyes shall be upon which people?
questions.explanation: David focuses on the faithful among the people (Psalm 101:6), emphasizing the value of godly fellowship. This is supported by Proverbs 12:26, 2 Timothy 2:22, Hebrews 10:24-25, and 1 Corinthians 15:33, which encourage association with the righteous.

questions.question: What does David say about those who work deceit in Psalms 101:7?
options: They shall not dwell within his house
They shall be welcomed with caution
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not dwell within his house
questions.explanation: Psalm 101:7 states that workers of deceit will not dwell with David, reflecting God's intolerance of falsehood and dishonesty (Proverbs 6:16-19, Psalm 34:13, Colossians 3:9, Ephesians 4:25).

questions.question: What action does David say he will take against all the wicked of the land in Psalms 101:8?
questions.explanation: Psalm 101:8 expresses David's resolve to cut off wicked doers quickly, illustrating God's righteous judgment. This parallels Ecclesiastes 8:11, Proverbs 11:31, Romans 12:19, and Revelation 21:8, which affirm divine justice against evil.

questions.question: What does 'walking in a perfect way' in Psalms 101:6 imply about the believer's conduct?
options: Living with integrity and obedience to God
questions.correctAnswer: Living with integrity and obedience to God
questions.explanation: Walking in a perfect way (Psalm 101:6) signifies wholehearted obedience and moral integrity before God, consistent with Micah 6:8, Matthew 22:37-40, Romans 12:1-2, and 1 John 2:6 which call for faithful discipleship.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is most reflected in David’s commitment to sing of mercy and judgment in Psalms 101:1?
questions.explanation: Psalm 101:1 highlights God's dual attributes of mercy and judgment, demonstrating His perfect balance of justice and compassion. This is affirmed in Exodus 34:6-7, Psalm 89:14, Romans 3:25-26, James 2:13, and Revelation 15:3.

questions.question: How does Psalms 101:4’s rejection of a 'froward heart' contribute to biblical teaching on sanctification?
options: It emphasizes the removal of sinful rebellion
It focuses on external ritual only
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the removal of sinful rebellion
questions.explanation: The departure of a froward heart (Psalm 101:4) points to the sanctification process where rebellion against God is removed. This aligns with Romans 8:13, 2 Corinthians 7:1, Hebrews 12:14, Galatians 5:16-17, and 1 Thessalonians 4:3.

questions.question: What does David’s vow in Psalms 101:5 about the proud and slanderers teach about the nature of sin in community?
options: Sin corrupts relationships and must be dealt with decisively
questions.correctAnswer: Sin corrupts relationships and must be dealt with decisively
questions.explanation: Psalm 101:5’s rejection of proud slanderers reveals sin’s destructive impact on community and the need for holiness. This is consistent with Leviticus 19:17, Proverbs 16:5, Ephesians 4:31-32, Colossians 3:8, and Matthew 18:15-17.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'he shall serve me' in Psalms 101:6 imply about the relationship between faithfulness and service to God?
questions.explanation: Psalm 101:6 links walking in a perfect way with serving God, showing that true faithfulness results in service. This connects with Joshua 24:15, Romans 12:1, Galatians 5:13, Colossians 3:23, and 1 Peter 4:10.

questions.question: How does Psalms 101:7’s rejection of liars contribute to understanding God’s holiness?
options: God’s holiness excludes deceit and falsehood
Liars can dwell with God if repentant only after death
questions.correctAnswer: God’s holiness excludes deceit and falsehood
questions.explanation: Psalm 101:7’s exclusion of liars reflects God’s nature as truth (John 14:6) and His call for holiness (Leviticus 19:11, Ephesians 4:25, Proverbs 12:22, 1 John 3:7).

questions.question: What eschatological implication can be drawn from David’s resolve in Psalms 101:8 to destroy the wicked early?
options: God’s final judgment will remove all wickedness
Wickedness is ultimately victorious until the end of time
questions.correctAnswer: God’s final judgment will remove all wickedness
questions.explanation: Psalm 101:8 anticipates God’s decisive judgment removing wickedness, resonating with Revelation 20:10, Daniel 12:2, 2 Peter 3:7, Matthew 25:41, and Romans 2:5-6, pointing to ultimate divine justice.
